PrimEcoSys: Inter-Mountain Basins Mixed Salt Desert Scrub

references: Griscom, H. Keinath, D. and M. Andersen. 2010. Pocket Gopher Surveys in Southwestern Wyoming.  Wyoming Natural Diversity Database.  39 pages.
Beauvais, G. P., and D. N. Dark-Smiley. 2005. Species assessment for Wyoming Pocket Gopher (Thomomys clusius) in Wyoming. US Bureau of Land Management. 30 pgs.
Keinath, D. A., Griscomm, H. R., and M. D. Andersen. 2014. Habitat and distribution of the Wyoming pocket gopher (Thomomys clusius). Journal of Mammalogy 95(4):803-813.

Keinath, D.A. and G.P. Beauvais. (2006, August 31). Wyoming Pocket Gopher (Thomomys clusius): a technical conservation assessment. [Online]. USDA  Forest  Service,  Rocky  Mountain  Region.  Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/r2/projects/scp/assessments/wyomingpocketgopher.pdf [June 12, 2015]
habitat_description: The Wyoming Pocket Gopher (Thomomys clusius) has a small and range and distribution that occurs within the range of the Northern Pocket Gopher.  It is not found west of the Green River.  Little was known about this species’ habitat or distribution until the work described by Keinath et al. (2014).  The region occupied by this species is dominated by Big sagebrush steppe communities, while other community types with plants like Gardner saltbush (Atriplex gardneri), yellow rabbitbrush, winterfat, and greasewood are interspersed within it.  Wyoming Pocket Gophers are more habitat specialist than Northern Pocket Gophers, and prefer areas with more bare ground, fewer surface rocks, less litter cover, less big sagebrush cover, less yellow rabbitbrush cover, greater Gardner’s saltbush cover, and greater winterfat cover (Keinath et al. 2014).   However, the presence of Gardner’s saltbush was the most definitive element of Wyoming Pocket Gopher habitat: they occurred in locations where Gardner’s saltbush grew, and Northern Pocket Gophers occurred in areas where it did not (Keinath et al. 2014).  T. clusius was negatively associated with sagebrush (Artemesia sp.). N. Tarr, 12June2015.
